title: If a1,a2,a3,…a(n) are in HP, then what is the value of the expression a1 a2+a2 a3+…+a(n-1) a(n)? - Quora

response.answer_text: Each answer should depend at least on two terms of the progression, since each HP is uniquely identified by two of its elements. In this caseI think the answer is [math]S_n=(n-1)a_1a_n.[/math] We can show it by induction on [math]n[/math]. Note that: [math]a_1a_2+a_2a_3 = a_1a_2a_3 \cdot \left( \frac{1}{a_1} + \frac{1}{a_3}\right)[/math] Now for each HP, for three consecutive items holds by definition: [math]\frac{1}{a_3}- \frac{1}{a_2}= \frac{1}{a_2}- \frac{1}{a_1}[/math] Which is equivalent to [math]\frac{1}{a_1}+ \frac{1}{a_3}=\frac{2}{a_2}[/math] Therefore [math]a_1a_2+a_2a_3 = 2a_1a_3[/math] This shows the case [math]n=2[/math], (n=1 is trivial) but it holds for each three consecutive elements in a HP. For larger value of [math]n[/math], we can apply induction. Then [math]S_n = S_{n-1}+a_{n-1}a_n=((n-1)-1)a_1a_{n-1}+a_{n-1}a_n = (n-2)a_1a_{n-1}+a_{n-1}a_n[/math] Similarly as before, now [math]S_n = a_1a_{n-1}a_n \cdot \left( \frac{n-2}{a_n} + \frac{1}{a_1} \right)[/math] By definition of HP (look at the indices: [math](n-1)-1 = (n-2) \cdot (n-(n-1))[/math]): [math]\frac{1}{a_{n-1}}- \frac{1}{a_1}=(n-2) \cdot \left( \frac{1}{a_n}- \frac{1}{a_{n-1}} \right)[/math] Which is equivalent to [math]\frac{n-2}{a_n}+ \frac{1}{a_1}=\frac{n-1}{a_{n-1}}[/math] Therefore [math]S_n = (n-1)a_1a_n[/math]
